text: The river Thames at daybreak, street-lamps reflected in t water. TILT UP to reveal the London Embankment, Big Ben i the background. Jack, an eternally optimistic lamplighter, climbs a ladde that leans against a lamppost, silhouetted against the da He dims the light and slides down to the ground. “LOVELY LONDON SKY"

head_text.subj: FOR WHEN ITS LIGHT HAS HIT THE GROUND
THERE'S LOTS OF TREASURES TO BE FOUND

text: Jack folds his ladder and fastens it to the back of his bicycle. He climbs on and rides off. EXT. THE DOCKS NEAR THE EMBANKMENT —- CONTINUOUS Dropping down from the rooftops of London, we discover workers unloading crates and barrels of fresh produce on docks. Jack slaloms through it all as he continues on his way.

head_text.subj: THOUGH THE LAMPS I'M TURNING DOWN
FOR IN THIS PART OF LONDON TOWN

text: Jack stops at a lamppost and dims the lamp. Ahead, NEEDY LONDONERS stand on a soup kitchen queue that snakes aroun the corner. VOLUNTEERS hand out food to them.

head_text.subj: DON'T BELIEVE THE THINGS YOU'VE READ
YOU NEVER KNOW WHAT'S UP AHEAD

text: Jack grabs an apple as he swerves past a fruit cart and tosses it to a MAN ON THE QUEUE.
Jack rides along the embankment, the bridge at his back.
As Jack rides down an alley adjacent to a pub, three STRE URCHINS chase behind him. An urchin helps him to shut off a street-lamp.

head_text.subj: THERE'S A DIFFERENT POINT OF VIEW
IF YOU WOULD JUST LOOK UP

text: A PUB LANDLORD sweeps the footpath.
Oi, get out of it! The urchins run off down the alley, as Jack rides down th street.
Jack passes St. Paul’s. A few HOMELESS PEOPLE sleep on th cathedral steps.

head_text.subj: BUT SINCE YOU DREAMED THE NIGHT AWAY
SO COUNT YOUR BLESSINGS, YOU'RE A

text: He rides through a flock of pigeons, scattering them, and taking us up past the dome.
CLOSE on Jack’s wheels as he winds his way through the pa As he rides along the path, he nods to a gruff PARK KEEPE spearing rubbish into a bag, who gives him a dirty look.
Jack whistles as he rides onto Cherry Tree Lane, a street lined with 19th-Century homes. He passes the neighboring MILKMAN, giving him a wave.

Mornin’, Jack! Jack glances up to a rooftop that has been fitted to look like the deck of a ship - at the moment, though, no one i the helm. He looks up, worried. Finally, the rooftop door creaks open and ADMIRAL BOOM appears, pushed in a wheelchair by his First Mate, BINNAC
(Blows whistle: ) Admiral... above decks! Jack smiles, saluting the sailors.
LISTEN... SOON THIS SLUMP’LL
IT WON’T BE LONG SOONER THAN ‘YA THINK YOU’LL HEAR

He sets up his ladder at the lamppost that stands before Cherry Tree Lane - a modest house which has fallen slight into disrepair. A BOY AND GIRL appear at the window in the upper floor of Banks home, waving. JACK (cont'd) Y’awright, children? Jack waves to the children. They wave back and exit. Jack climbs the ladder. JACK (cont'd)

head_text.subj: SO HOLD ON TIGHT TO THOSE YOU LOVE
AND MAYBE SOON FROM UP ABOVE
YOU'LL BE BLESSED SO KEEP ON

text: Jack dims the light and glances up into the sky. He slide down the ladder, climbs onto his bicycle and rides off. BIG BEN TOLLS eight o’clock in the distance. A black car pulls up as Jack rides off. Two men in suits get out of the car: GOODING and FRYE. T men set their watches by the toll of the bell, then walk the path to the house. UP ABOVE, the Admiral and Binnacle have just made it acro the rooftop. The Admiral is outraged.
Great steaming clams - they’ve done it again! Those blundering blowfish have rung Big Ben too soon!
Storm clouds on the horizon, Sir. Heading straight for Cherry Tree Lane.
Batten down the hatches, Mr. Binnacle. Rough seas ahead, I fear. Both men react as a SCREAM comes from the Bank’s househol
Inside the Banks family home, the house shows some signs wear and inattention.
(The scream continues: )
The door that leads into the kitchen flies open - water c be seen spraying the room. ELLEN, the housekeeper, runs i the hall in a panic and calls upstairs. ELLEN (cont'd)
JANE and MICHAEL BANKS rush in from the parlor behind Ell
What is it, Ellen?
The bloomin’ sink’s exploded!
Not again!
Oh dear.  Michael rushes into the kitchen. The boy and girl we saw earlier, ANNABEL and JOHN, run down the steps. AUNT JANE (cont'd) Oh - Annabel, John - !
We heard, Aunt Jane - I'll ring the plumbers!
I’ll turn off the water at the mains! John runs down into the cellar.
(Going into the kitchen: ) Thank you, darlings - Ellen, fetch us a mop and towels, will you?

(Grumbling to herself:) I told ‘im to get them pipes fixed. They been there since the Romans ruled. Ellen disappears into the cellar. GEORGIE comes down the stairs, carrying his stuffed giraffe, “Gillie.”
What’s happening?

Don’t go in the kitchen, Georgie - not without your Wellies -— (On phone: ) Yes, hello. We’ve had a burst pipe. (There is a TAPPING at the front door. On phone:) Excuse me — (Calling: ) Ellen, could you please get the door? I’ve got the plumbers here. Ellen comes out of the cellar with the mop and towels.

That was quick work, wasn’t it? Hands full, she gives the towels to Georgie. ELLEN (cont'd) Here Georgie - take these. (Heading to the door:) Alright, alright - I’m coming. Gooding and Frye stand outside, tacking up a notice.
Ah. Good morning, mum.
They don’t look like plumbers.
(Looks over.) I meant on the phone.
We are not plumbers - we’re lawyers.
Lawyers? Here’s me, hopin’ you'd prove useful. She absentmindedly hands the mop to Gooding and shuts the Aunt Jane her dress She wraps
Water’s off!
(hanging up) And the plumbers are on their way. comes out of the kitchen, her hair and the front of drenched with water.
Well done, everyone. Phew! Such excitement!
What are you doing here, Aunt Jane?

(She takes a towel from Georgie to dry off:) We’re handing out breakfasts at the union hall. I snuck away for morning hugs. Come here. the towel around Georgie and gives the three children a hug. Aunt Jane takes the towels and heads back into the kitche Georgie picks up a towel she has accidentally dropped, following her into the kitchen. There’s a knock at the door. Ellen goes over and opens it
Will you stop that bangin’? It’s barely eight o’clock on a Sunday mornin’! (more)  ELLEN (cont'd) (She sees her mop, grabs it:) Wot’cher doin’ with my mop?
Forgive the intrusion, mum. Our current workload prevents us taking weekends off.
We would like to have a word with Mr. Banks, if he is available. Ellen finally sees the notice on the door.

“Notice of... Repossession?” Frye, by far the more sympathetic of the two, sighs loudl and nods sadly, looking genuinely pained. Ellen glares. ELLEN (cont'd) Wait there. She goes back inside. John and Annabel quickly turn away, pretending not to be paying attention. The lawyers peer through the door as Michael re-enters from the kitchen, thoroughly soaked, followed by Georgie. As Michael takes his jacket:
I'll be cleaning up that mess all morning.
(Reaching for the jacket:) Here. Let me take that, father.
Oh, thank you, darling. Annabel runs upstairs with the jacket.
(Undisguised contempt: ) “Scuse me, sir - the wolves are at the door.
What do they want?
A good thrashin’, if you ask me. (She looks into the kitchen, sighs.) Looks like the River Thames in there.  Aunt Jane comes out as Michael takes the mop from Ellen.
Don’t worry - I’ll clean up, Ellen. Why don’t you see to breakfast?
Suppose someone ‘as to - ‘less we all want to starve. She goes into the kitchen.
(Aside, to Michael: ) Why don’t you let Ellen clean up?

(A resigned sigh:) I'm afraid lately that means more work for me. The other day I found a butcher’s sack hanging on the coat rack - and my hat was in the larder. Aunt Jane catches sight of her damp hair in the hall mirr
I need a brush - I look a fright. (As she goes upstairs: ) Don’t forget you have guests at the door, Michael.
Right - (He goes to the door, dodging the children) I'm sorry. We're struggling through a bit of chaos this morning - They take a step into the hallway. Michael closes the doo behind them.
So it seems. Unfortunately, Mr. Banks, our business cannot wait. Ellen reappears from the kitchen.
Excuse me, sir - how exactly am I supposed to make breakfast when there’s nothing in the larder but pickled herring and marmalade?
(Hand to forehead: ) The groceries - I meant to go yesterday.
(She nods, turns to go.) Very well, then. Pickled herring for breakfast, marmalade for lunch.
(Once Ellen has gone:) That little shop across the park will be open. The three of us can go.
Oh, thank you, John.
(Aside, to Annabel: ) But you said we would go to the park today!
We'll cut through the park on the way.
But -
Enough, Georgie. Come along. John takes the mop from Michael.
I'll take that, Father.

Thank you. Aunt Jane comes back downstairs as the twins lead Georgie into the kitchen. Michael gestures for the lawyers to joi him in the parlor. Aunt Jane follows, putting on her coat MICHAEL (cont'd) Please, come through -
Now, what is it I can do for you?
I am Hamilton Gooding; this is Mr. Templeton Frye. We are solicitors with the law firm of Gordy, Cordry, Gooding and Frye. Aunt Jane suppresses a laugh.  10 GOODING (cont'd) What?
Nothing. Gooding notices the poster sticking out of Aunt Jane’s notebook.
SPRUCE? Is that your garden club?
No, it’s the “Society for the Protection of the Rights of the Underpaid Citizens of England.”
A labour organizer? (Archly polite, to Frye:) She's a labour organizer. Gooding and Frye sit on the sofa. Michael sits in the armchair opposite. Aunt Jane moves round, tying her belt.
Well, yes - we also run soup kitchens - it’s a never-ending job these days.
I’m sure it is, Mrs. Banks.
Miss Banks, actually. I’m Michael’s sister.
My wife passed away this last year.
That’s awful! Those poor children.
Our deepest condolences.
Thank you. Forgive me - what brings the two of you here this morning?
I’m going to say my good-byes. Aunt Jane kisses Michael on the cheek and heads out.  11
Mr. Banks, you took out a loan with Fidelity Fiduciary Bank last year against the value of your home. Aunt Jane stops and steps back to Michael.
You did what? Michael!
I had to, Jane. I didn’t have much choice, what with Kate and the bills piling up -
Hard enough these days, isn’t it?
Yes, well, it seems you’ve fallen three months behind in payments -
I am sorry. Kate, my wife, used to handle all our finances, you see, and I’ve been a bit off my stride. (Stands, walks to desk:) How much is it I owe you exactly?
Unfortunately, the bank is now demanding you pay back the entire loan in full.
The entire loan?
Yes - it’s all in the contract.
That’s more than I make in a year. I couldn’t possibly.
Oh dear! Gooding stands to leave, picking up his hat and briefcase

You have five days. If you are unable to pay in full by Friday at midnight, I’m afraid we will have to repossess your home, and you will have to vacate the premises. Frye sighs, distraught. Gooding glances over, irritated.  12
But I work at Fidelity Fiduciary!
Not as an accountant, I presume.
No, as a teller - I took a part- time position there this past year. You see, I’m really an artist -
Be that as it may -
But my father, George Banks, was a senior partner there!
(A realization: ) Father left us bank shares! You could use them to pay off the loan.
I was saving those for the children, but - Frye stands.
Shares? In the bank? (Brightly, to Gooding: ) That does change things, doesn’t it?
Do you have the share certificate?
Sorry? The what?
The document —
The document proving you own shares in the bank.

... I suppose it must be somewhere among father’s old papers. EXT. THE ADMIRAL’S ROOFTOP - CONTINUOUS On the rooftop next door, the Admiral and Binnacle are finally prepared to fire off the 8 a.m. cannon.  13
Primed and ready, Mr. Binnacle?
Ready and charged, sir.
On my mark. Three, two, one - FIRE!
Inside, the cannon fire rattles the walls, knocking everything askew and terrifying the lawyers. A clock and urn land in Gooding’s hands. Ash flies out of the firepla
Good heavens! Are you housing anarchists? Michael and Aunt Jane behave as though this is perfectly normal; they begin pushing all the furniture and belongin back into place as they speak.
No, that’s the Admiral. He fires off a cannon to mark the hour.
(He checks his watch:) But he’s over five minutes late.
Yes, I’m afraid he’s been running a little behind these last few years. Michael and Aunt Jane push the piano back in place.
As are we, this morning. You’ve been given notice; (Hands Michael the notice) We'll see ourselves out. Come along, Mr. Frye.
(putting on his hat) I hope you find that share certificate. I really do.
Good day to you both. (As they leave, to Frye:) You really have chosen the wrong profession, you know... The door shuts.
Why didn’t you tell me you had taken out a loan, Michael? Michael moves away from Jane.

I didn’t want to worry you - or the children. I kept thinking I would catch up. Kate always managed. (He shakes his head:) Of all the thick-headed mistakes... I can’t lose our home, Jane. She’s everywhere here.

Well then we aren’t going to let that happen. But, Michael, you know we neither of us have enough money between us - so we just have to find that share certificate. Do you have any idea where father might have kept it?
Up in the attic, I suppose... (He tucks away his emotions, smiles.) «+. I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to bring you into all this.
(Exasperated: ) Michael! This is our family home, and you're about to lose it - so stop pretending everything’s fine.
Are we going to lose our home? 14 Michael and Aunt Jane turn. Georgie and the twins, having entered from the dining room in their coats and wellies, been listening to them.
Oh, no - no, of course not, Georgie.
I was saying you won’t have to worry, because your father owns shares in the bank.
But you said we don’t have enough money. Michael grabs paper and pen and sketches something.  15
Well, I can make more - I ama banker now, aren’t I? That’s what bankers do - make money.
But you’re not a banker - you’re a painter.
Yes, well - painters don’t make money. Not these days. Here, you see? The day has hardly begun and I’ve already made you 10 pounds.
Michael hands Georgie what he’s drawn - a decent likeness a 10-pound note. Annabel and John exchange a glance, seei through Michael's false cheer instantly. Georgie smiles.
(Looking at his watch:) We'd best be going.
Let’s get your hats on then. Annabel goes to the front hall coat rack to get their hat
(With a wink, handing a few coins to John:) John, one moment. Georgie shouldn't have to spend his 10 pounds on the shopping - here you are.
Thank you, father.
(Entering: ) Off to the park now, I see.
Yes - that’s right, Ellen. Ellen helps the children with their hats. Aunt Jane takes her coat as she heads for the stairs.
(To Michael: ) Shall we search the attic, then?
Don’t you have to go to work?  16
(Rolling up her sleeves: ) Work can wait. Michael follows her up the stairs.
Thank you, Jane - yes, I’1l1 look in the attic. Why don’t you check father’s old wardrobe? Ellen follows the children to the front door.
We’ll make lunch when we get home, Ellen. Annabel takes Gillie from Georgie, handing it to Ellen.
Gillie stays here.
(As the children leave: ) Blimey - such little grown-ups you've become.
Annabel reads over the shopping list as the children walk through the park.
Father didn’t give us enough, did he?
Not nearly.
We can ask for day-old bread at half off; that’s what mother used to do. Georgie smiles, seeing MISS LARK, the children’s wealthy neighbor, walking her dog WILLOUGHBY.
Hello, Willoughby! Hello, Miss Lark!
Hello, Georgie! Twins.
Come on Georgie, we haven't got time for this.  17 Willoughby barks. Georgie notices a woman selling balloon (BALLOON LADY) in the distance. He cuts across the grass toward her:
The balloon lady! Can we get balloons?
No, Georgie - we haven’t enough for groceries as it is. The Park Keeper appears, calling to Georgie.
Oi, Georgie Banks - keep off the grass! I don’t spend all day caring for it just to see my work get trampled on! Go on, hop it! Georgie sighs and reluctantly returns to the path.
Sorry.
(Quietly, to Annabel: What if Father does lose the house?
We'll just have to figure out a way to get it back, I suppose.
You're right... That’s what mother would do.

The attic is a complete mess. Michael’s easels, canvases art supplies are all piled up in a corner. Michael goes o to an old desk. He searches through its drawers, then pic up a wooden storage crate. Inside the crate, Michael finds a jewelry box with an engraved “K” on its lid. When he opens it, a gentle melod plays. He takes out a necklace of his wife’s, gazing at i moment. He sets the box aside and continues searching the attic, still holding the necklace - but he can’t get the gentle melody out of his head... “A CONVERSATION"

head_text.subj: WE HAVEN'T SPOKEN IN SO LONG DEAR
THIS YEAR HAS GONE BY IN A BLUR
TODAY SEEMS EVERYTHING'S GONE WRONG HERE

text: (more)  18 MICHAEL (cont'd) I’M LOOKING FOR THE WAY THINGS WERE I KNOW YOU’D LAUGH AND CALL ME TRAGIC

head_text.subj: THESE ROOMS WERE ALWAYS FULL OF MAGIC
THAT'S VANISHED SINCE YOU WENT AWAY
THIS HOUSE IS CROWDED NOW WITH QUESTIONS
AND I COULD SURELY USE A FEW SUGGESTIONS

text: ON HOW TO BRUSH OUR DAUGHTER’S HAIR

head_text.subj: YOU ALWAYS KNEW JUST WHAT TO SAY
AND I MISS OUR FAMILY CONVERSATIONS
IT'S SILENT SINCE YOU WENT AWAY

text: Michael looks out of the window.

head_text.subj: BUT THE CHERRY TREES FORGOT TO BLOOM

text: He reminds himself to keep searching. The certificate... The certificate...

head_text.subj: I'LL CARRY ON THE WAY YOU TOLD ME
I SAY THAT LIKE I HAVE A CHOICE
AND THOUGH YOU ARE NOT HERE TO HOLD ME
IN THE ECHOES I CAN HEAR YOUR VOICE
BUT STILL ONE QUESTION FILLS MY DAY DEAR
THE ANSWER I'VE MOST LONGED TO KNOW
EACH MOMENT SINCE YOU WENT AWAY DEAR
MY QUESTION, KATE, IS "WHERE'D YOU GO

text: As Aunt Jane enters, Michael puts away the necklace and closes the lid of the jewelry box, turning away to hide h emotions.
Nothing in the wardrobe. (Gazing around the attic:) Oh my goodness.
(He turns back, smiling: ) Yes, it’s quite a mess, isn’t it? Aunt Jane notices Michael's art supplies.
What are all your art things doing up here?  19
I wasn’t using them anymore. I should probably get rid of it all.
Have you looked in father’s old desk?

(pulling out an old snowglobe) I honestly don’t know why we kept most of this stuff to begin with. He reaches into a nearby box and pulls out an old, patche kite with a suffragette banner for a tail. MICHAEL (cont'd) I mean, why on Earth did we save this old broken thing?
Don’t you remember that kite? We used to love flying that with mother and father.
Well, it won't fly anymore. Out it goes - no looking back. Michael throws the beaten kite into the rubbish box and carries it to the door.

location: THE HOUSE AT 17 CHERRY TREE LANE

text: Michael carries the trash bin out to leave by the side of house, then goes back inside. A beat, and then the wind stirs. The kite shudders and lifts into the air, blown ou the trash bin. It skitters across the lane, past Jack, who is riding his bicycle. He stops in his tracks, watching the kite skip b The behavior of this kite strikes him as unusual, to say least. He glances up, sensing something in the air.
(Singing softly:)

head_text.subj: HOLD ON TIGHT TO THOSE YOU LOVE
AND MAYBE SOON FROM UP ABOVE...

text: He pedals off in pursuit. EXT. THE PARK —- CONTINUOUS In the park, Willoughby the dog sees the kite tumble past barks madly.  20 The kite swings up to hit a MAN ON A PARK BENCH in the ba of the head, knocking off his bowler hat. Barely reacting the man calmly sets his hat back in place and continues reading a newspaper. Up ahead, the twins are poring over their errand list; Georgie, lagging behind, sees the kite tumble past - he chases after it.
How long do you think it will take us today?
Well, let’s see. It’s a nine minute walk to the shop. If it takes about ten minutes to purchase each item, we should be back home by- Jack races past John and Annabel on his bicycle.
‘Scuse me, children - coming through!
Georgie! Come back!
Georgie! The twins start after Georgie, but the Park Keeper sees t
You two - off the grass!
But our brother -

You heard me - now! A gust of wind sends the kite over a hedge. Georgie scram through the hedge into a CLEARING, getting his clothes covered in mud. The kite is there, leaning against a ston bridge as though waiting for him. Georgie runs to it, pul out the spool of string that’s been tucked in its frame a raises the kite into the air. Clouds gather and roil. The wind grows violent, dragging Georgie off his feet as the shoots up through the clouds. John and Annabel are rushing along the path when they hea
Help! The twins charge out across the grass and dive under the hedge.  21
WE’RE COMING GEORGIE! Jack, meanwhile, stops his bike on the nearby path and hurries over to rescue Georgie.

Hold on...! Jack grabs hold of Georgie, pulls him down. They both pul the kite string with all their might. The sky begins to c the clouds part, and a figure, holding onto the kite’s ta comes into view... It is MARY POPPINS! Dressed in a long coat, scarf, and eccentric hat, Mary Poppins carries a carpetbag in her free hand and has a pa headed umbrella tucked under her arm. JACK (cont'd) As I live and breathe... The twins scramble through the bushes just in time to see Mary Poppins glide the last five or so feet to the ground The moment Mary Poppins lands, she addresses Georgie. Jac reels in the kite string. Brusquely:

You need to be more careful when the wind rises, Georgie - you nearly lost your kite. (As the twins approach: ) And you two nearly lost your Georgie. He might have got away completely had I’d not been holding on to the other end of that string. She brushes herself off, taking note of the children’s appearances. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) My goodness, Annabel - what have you done to your clothes? You could grow a garden in that much soil. And John, you're just as filthy.
How do you know our names?
(Beaming: ) Because she’s Mary Poppins, of course! And may I say you look lovely, as always.  22
You really think so? It is nice to see you, Jack -
Good to see you too, Mary Poppins. (To the children: ) I was just your age when we first met, working for a chimney sweep. Jack hands the kite back to Georgie.
How is dear old Bert?
Traveling the world he is, off to points unknown.

Well, now I am off to speak with the father of these children - this family is clearly in desperate need of a nanny. (To the children: ) Now, quick march and best foot forward, and I’ll thank you not to dawdle. Mary Poppins marches off, Georgie at her side. The twins exchange a puzzled glance.
Go on. The twins then hurry after their brother. Jack follows be and picks up his bike off the ground.
Georgie charges into the hall, and shouts up the stairs.
Father! Aunt Jane - come quick! Michael rushes to the top of the steps. Georgie stands at base of the stairs holding the weatherbeaten kite, excite
What is it, Georgie?
Has something happened?
I was flying a kite and it got caught on a nanny!  23 Michael and Aunt Jane come downstairs.
Whatever are you talking about?
Come look!
Wait - where did you get that kite?

I found it in the park. (Pointing to the door:) She kept it from blowing away. They look toward the front door as Mary Poppins steps int the house for the first time in decades. Michael is so ta aback that he drops the papers he holds.
Mary... ?
-+. Poppins?

Close your mouth please, Michael. We are still not a codfish. Aunt Jane giggles. Mary Poppins gives her a sidelong glan MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Jane Banks - still rather inclined to giggle I see. This stops Aunt Jane. Michael beams. Annabel and John run closing the door behind them.
-+. Good heavens, it really is you! You seem hardly to have aged at all.
Really! How rude. One never discusses a woman’s age, Michael. I would have hoped I had taught you better.
I’m sorry, I didn’t mean -
You came back! I thought we’d never see you again.  24
It is wonderful to see you -
(Admiring herself in the mirror: ) Yes, it is, isn’t it.
You know her then? As Mary Poppins crosses away from the mirror, her reflect remains behind, watching her go.
Yes. Mary Poppins used to be our nanny.
What brings you here after all this time?
The same thing that brought me the first time: I’ve come to look after the Banks children. The twins exchange a look.
Us?
(Turning: ) .«.. Oh, yes - you too.
(A little huffy: ) But we don’t need a nanny. Mother taught us to look after ourselves.
You did just misplace Georgie, I might point out.
Only slightly. We got him back.
We can do anything a nanny can.
Mary Poppins flew here on a kite. You can’t do that, can you?
What are you talking about, Georgie? Don’t be silly.  25

Oh, let him believe what he likes. (To Georgie: ) When your father and I were young, we used to imagine Mary Poppins could do all sorts of impossible things. Georgie alone notices the parrot on the handle of Mary Poppins’ umbrella coming to life.
(Squawking: ) Actually - Mary Poppins calmly pinches the parrot’s beak shut.
‘Actually,’ what?
Actually, I’d like to get back to the matter of my employment.
Your umbrella talks!
Georgie, please - we're in the midst of a grown-up conversation.
Why don’t we go upstairs, Georgie?
But it did talk! I promise - The twins lead Georgie upstairs. Once they’ve gone:
I'm afraid sometimes Georgie suffers from an excess of imagination.
As I recall, you had the same affliction yourself when you were young.
Did I, really? Well, those days are long behind me.
Are they, indeed? (She nods, confirming something to herself.) About my employment, then -  26
Yes, about that - the truth is, I simply can’t afford -
We can settle on terms later, although I will want my old room back, as long as it’s not a complete disaster, and I insist on having every second Tuesday off.
But I’m afraid -
Of course, Mary Poppins. Michael shoots Aunt Jane a look.

Good, good. That’s all settled. Then I’1l stay. Now, if you'll excuse me, the children have turned themselves into dustbins; my first order of business is to see them properly bathed and dressed. Michael pulls Aunt Jane into the living room.
Have you gone completely mad, Jane? I can’t afford to take on anyone else.
Mary Poppins isn’t just anyone. Don’t you see, Michael? No one’s hiring nannies anymore. The poor woman has no place to go.
Neither will we by the end of the week.
Oh, don’t be so grumpy. You sound just like father.
I do not!
Give Mary Poppins a chance. You need help just as much as she does.

Oh... very well. She can stay for the time being, I suppose. (more)  27 MICHAEL (cont'd) (Ironically: ) After all, she did fly all this way on a kite. They share a laugh. Aunt Jane smiles, hesitates. Behind them, Mary Poppins hops on the bannister and glide the stairs, leaving her bag and umbrella behind.
Those things, when we were young - they didn’t really...
(With a smile:) Happen? No...
No, of course not.
Ridiculous. They laugh.
Mary Poppins glides up the bannister past Ellen, carrying armful of fresh towels.
Oh hello, Mary Poppins.
Hello, Ellen. Mary Poppins hops off the bannister. Georgie is waiting f her. His jaw drops as the parrot umbrella and her carpetb float down from above and into her hands.
How did you do that?
Do what?
And why didn’t father believe you flew here on a kite?
Because it’s complete nonsense, of course.
(Squawking: ) Grown-ups forget. They always do.  28
(A sharp look: ) That will be quite enough of that. I should have left you in the umbrella stand.
(Aghast: ) Not with the canes! Mary Poppins marches into the nursery, Georgie behind her
John and Annabel are huddled together, talking in hushed tones, when Mary Poppins arrives.
What are you two whispering about?
(Coming to attention: ) Nothing.
(removing her hat) “Nothing” is such a useful word, isn’t it? It can mean anything and everything.
It’s just that -
- you don’t require the services of a nanny.
Well, we have grown up a good deal in the past year, after all.
Yes, yes. We’ll have to see what can be done about that. Mary Poppins straightens the items on the fireplace. She reaches to adjust a china bowl on the mantelpiece.
That was our mother’s - be careful.
(Haughtily: ) I am always careful. Mary Poppins unties her jacket belt.  29
(Anxious: ) So... you’re staying?
(removing her jacket belt) Yes, I’1l stay... until the door opens.
What does that mean?
(Looking to the nursery door.) That door is always opening. Mary Poppins unbuttons and removes her coat.
Not that door - another one. Mary Poppins opens the cupboard doors and takes out some clothes.
(Incredulous: ) The bathroom door?
That’s just silly, Georgie. (To Mary Poppins, uncertain: ) Not the bathroom door?
(As she heads off:) No. But a bath would prove useful. Come along - time for a good, clean start.
Steam clouds fill the air. Georgie and the twins stand in their 1930's-style long underwear, watching as Mary Poppi draws a bath. The twins aren’t in the least happy about i
Our mother always had us take our baths in the evening.

In my experience, the perfect time of day to have a bath is when one needs a wash. Georgie will go first.  30 Mary Poppins gathers towels and washcloths, shampoo and a fresh bar of soap, which she places beside the tub.
We are perfectly capable of drawing our own baths.
How very helpful John. In that case, you may turn off the tap. (He reaches to do so.) But not quite yet - we still have to put in the bubbles.
But I don’t like soap bubbles. Mary Poppins goes off to retrieve her bag.
Then you shall have to try to avoid them at all costs.
(Quietly, to Annabel: She's a tough nut, isn’t she?
(Aloud: ) Alright then, but we’ll have to get this done quickly.
Right, we still have to get to the grocers - and it looks as though it might rain.
I know who you should ask.
Her umbrella can’t talk, Georgie. Mary Poppins returns with her carpetbag, shaking her head
The very idea.
How do you know it can’t?
Because it can’t. The very notion is ridiculous.
Exactly right, Annabel. It’s nonsense. Foolishness.  31
It makes no sense. And if it makes no sense it can’t be true. Mary Poppins pulls a bottle of soa uu. es from her bag. ‘Yy ppi pull b 1 £ p bubbl £ he bag “CAN YOU IMAGINE THAT?"
IT’S GOOD TO KNOW YOU'RE BRIGHT

head_text.subj: FOR INTELLECT CAN WASH AWAY CONFUSION

text: MOST FOLDEROL’S AN OPTICAL ILLUSION... YOU THREE KNOW IT’S TRUE

head_text.subj: THAT ONE PLUS ONE IS TWO
YES, LOGIC IS THE ROCK OF OUR FOUNDATION...

text: (AND I’M NEVER INCORRECT) THAT YOU’RE FAR TOO OLD TO GIVE IN TO IMAGINATION... As she pours the soap bubbles into the bath, a dolphin pe it's head up out of the water, much to the children’s amazement. To the dolphin: Not yet. Mary Poppins gently pushes the dolphin back underwater.

head_text.subj: SOME PEOPLE LIKE TO SPLASH AND PLAY

text: Mary Poppins reaches into her bag to pull out a pail and shovel and a rubber duck. The children watch, astonished.

head_text.subj: AND SEND IT DOWN THE DRAIN

text: As Mary Poppins drops each item into the tub, they seem t magically drawn into the water, as though rocketing down slide.

head_text.subj: SOME PEOPLE LIKE TO LAUGH AT LIFE

text: THEY THINK THE WORLD’S A BRAND NEW SHINY TOY She pulls a toy pirate ship out of her bag, puts it into tub and it disappears; then she sprinkles a handful of co into the water.  32 MARY POPPINS (cont'd)

head_text.subj: AND IF WHILE DREAMING IN THE CLOUDS

text: Mary Poppins searches in her bag for something, snapping fingers when she suddenly remembers where it is. She marc over and pulls a large beach umbrella out of the sink wit flourish, then slides it into the tub as well. ALTHOUGH THEY’RE DOWN AND BENT IN HALF

head_text.subj: THEY BRUSH RIGHT OFF AND START TO LAUGH

text: On second thoughts, perhaps you’re right. It makes no sense to have a bath this early -
I want to take a bath!

(Mildly surprised: ) Oh, really? Very well, then... Up you go... and in you go! She sets Georgie on the edge of the tub. He throws up his arms and slides in - he too is magically drawn into the water.
Georgie! John lunges forward, grabbing Georgie’s hand at the last possible moment - getting pulled into the water as well.
John! Annabel sweeps away soap bubbles and peers into the water Georgie and John are nowhere to be seen. ANNABEL (cont'd) What happened? Will they be alright?
It is just a bath, after all. But then again, it’s not my tub.
Shouldn’t you go after them?
I had my bath this morning, thank you.
Well, if you won’t, I will!  33 Annabel climbs onto the back of the tub and slides in. Mary Poppins sits on the edge of the tub herself, and sli in backwards -
Off we go!

Georgie, the twins and Mary Poppins plummet past, all of tumbling down into a magical ocean. The toys Mary Poppins in the water have all grown to enormous size. The rubber is the size of a bus; the pail and shovel are enormous.

head_text.subj: SOME PEOPLE LIKE TO DIVE RIGHT IN
AND FLAP ABOUT IN BATHTUB GIN

text: Mary Poppins and the children float past increasingly sur scenes peopled by those they know from Cherry Tree Lane. Lark passes by with her dog Willoughby on a leash, the do towing her as he paddles through the water.
BUT WE KNOW IT’S NOT SO! The toy pirate ship has become a full-size shipwreck. Ell can be seen through a hole in the ship’s hull, trying to the clams and minnows in her cooking pot from swimming aw

head_text.subj: AND HEAVEN KNOWS WHAT LIVES WITHIN THAT POT

text: A treasure chest sits on a reef, filled with the coins sh dropped in. They swim down to it, coins swirling around t in a current.

head_text.subj: THEY SEARCH THE WORLD FOR BURIED GOLD

text: Georgie veers away from the others, diving through thick seagrass. He looks up. The Park Keeper stands before him, pointing sternly to a sign: “KEEP OFF THE SEAGRASS.” THEY WON’T GROW UP AND DON’T GROW OLD!

Mary Poppins grabs sponges from a colorful coral reef and tosses them to the children.  34 MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Be sure to scrub behind your ears! Mary Poppins floats up toward the surface as a SCHOOL OF DOLPHINS arrives and circles around the children, creatin whirlpool of bubbles. When the dolphins swim off and the bubbles clear, the children are thoroughly scrubbed and washed. The children are captured in enormous bubbles; on one, they float to the surface...

location: THE MAGICAL OCEAN, ABOVE THE WATER

text: The bubbles lift out of the water to hover above Mary Poppins, who sits in their bathtub, which is now floating an endless sea. Mary Poppins takes the beach umbrella, which sits in the and uses it to pop the children’s bubbles. They all land the tub.
Mary Poppins raises the umbrella for a sail, handing it t John.
The Admiral and Binnacle float past them in a rowboat.
AS IT’S OWN REWARD
Ahoy!
THEY ROCK THE BOAT, THEN — The Admiral and Binnacle salute. The children salute back John is pulled off balance by the umbrella and falls in.
-— MAN OVERBOARD! Mary Poppins and the children reel John back onboard.  35

head_text.subj: SOME PEOPLE LOOK OUT ON THE SEA
AND SEE A BRAND NEW DAY

text: Yet...

head_text.subj: AND THEY SINK IN SECONDS FLAT

text: So... PERHAPS WE’VE LEARNT WHEN DAY IS DONE

head_text.subj: SOME STUFF AND NONSENSE COULD BE

text: Mary Poppins pulls the string of the bathtub stopper. Wat rushes up through the drain, and a whirlpool opens up ben the tub. Everyone tumbles about as the tub spins down int the yawning vortex, spinning faster and faster...

«+. water swirling down the drain. The children are back the bathroom, wrapped in towels. All that’s left in the t is the toy duck. The children watch in mute awe as Mary Poppins picks it up and slips into her carpetbag, closing latch just as the song ends.
Michael pulls books off of shelves, searching for the sha document; Aunt Jane looks through the bottom drawer of th secretary desk, pulling out stacks of pencil drawings. Michael turns to Aunt Jane.
Anything?
No, just your drawings, and bills - and nothing else.
(After a beat: ) Then it’s not here. The children can be heard coming downstairs as Michael ta the drawings from Aunt Jane and tosses them onto the floo
(Overlapping: ) Father, Aunt Jane! / You won’t believe it! / It was incredible!  36 The children appear in the doorway, Mary Poppins behind t
We went sailing!
Not now, please -
But it really happened! Tell them, Mary Poppins!
I have no idea what you’re all talking about.
We swam through a pirate ship -
Enough - PLEASE! The children’s wonder has faded in an instant.
You're right, father. We’re sorry. She takes Georgie’s hand and turns to go.
(Contrite: ) No, wait - I’m sorry. I don’t mean to be cross with all of you. I’ve just lost something very important.
And we'll find it. I’m sure your grandfather just tucked it away somewhere for safekeeping - (A realization: ) The bank! Didn’t father have a safety deposit box in the bank?
Yes, he did!
Well, let’s go!
It’s closed.
We'll go first thing in the morning.
Won’t we need a key?  37
There’s a whole drawer full of keys up in father’s desk.
Is there?
Yes. Michael and Aunt Jane hurry out of the room. Mary Poppins shakes her head, dismayed at the mess they’ve left behind

My goodness, gracious, glory me! You'd think by now they’d have learned to pick up after themselves. As she picks up a piece of paper and drops it into the rubbish bin, the other papers on the floor magically RISE INTO THE AIR, swirl around the room, then collect themsel together and fall neatly into the rubbish bin. ONE FINAL DRAWING lands gently on top of the rest. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Cleaning is not a spectator sport, I‘1l remind you. John, Annabel, put all the books back on the shelves - (Handing Georgie the bin:) - Georgie Banks, come back here. Take out this rubbish, would you?
Yes, Mary Poppins.
There’s a good boy. Off you go, spit spot.

As Georgie struggles to carry the bin, he pauses to look the final drawing that landed in the pile, which shows a playful depiction of the house in happier times, when mot was still alive. In the drawing, Father stands in front of the house with arms around John and Annabel and mother cradles Georgie i her arms. Everyone beams with happiness. Georgie takes th drawing out of the bin, folds it and puts it in his pocke
ESTABLISHING SHOT - The next morning. It is raining; a se black umbrellas swirl along the sidewalk outside the bank  38
CLOSE on a safety deposit box. Michael flips through a sm stack papers as Aunt Jane watches. He finds nothing.
Well. That’s that. Michael puts everything back into the box and gestures fo BANK OFFICER to lock it away again.
What about Mr. Dawes, Jr.? Couldn’t he give you more time?
I’m sure he would if he were still here. Dawes’ nephew has been running things lately. I’m not even sure he knows who I am.
(She rises, heading for the door:) Well, it’s high time he finds out, don’t you think?
Jane - ? Jane!
By the time Michael leaves the vault, Aunt Jane is halfwa across the bank. He tries to get Aunt Jane’s attention as strides up the staircase at the far end of the main floor
(Whispered: ) Jane... Jane! INT. OUTSIDE MR. WILKINS’ OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
We can’t just charge into his office. Aunt Jane arrives at the desk of MISS PENNY FARTHING (30s Mr. Wilkins’ receptionist; Michael is not far behind.

Hello, Miss... (Off her name plaque:) .+. Penny Farthing, is it? Heavens, did the old secretary finally retire? (more)  39 AUNT JANE (cont'd) She always had that jar of sweets on the desk that we would raid as children - MR. WILKINS (50s, patrician, sporting a thin, waxed musta sticks his head out of his office, a kindly smile on his
I remember that jar - with those little toffees that stuck your teeth together. We must get you one of those jars, Miss Farthing.
Of course, sir.
This wouldn’t happen to be your sister, would it, Mr. Banks?
Yes - Jane Banks. How do you do? They shake hands.

Great pleasure to meet you -- William Weatherall Wilkins. (Waving them in:) Do step this way. Michael blinks, surprised. Aunt Jane smiles. INT. WILKINS’ OFFICE - DAY A SHORT TIME LATER: Wilkins sits at the desk, examining paperwork as Michael and Aunt Jane look on. He has an enormous office with a roaring fireplace and a view of Bi Ben out the window behind his desk.
If I had known George Banks’ son had taken a loan with us, I’d have handled the paperwork myself. Unfortunately, regarding the extension, there’s very little I can do at this point.
Our father did leave us shares in the bank. This is news to Wilkins. He looks up, smiling with intere
Oh, well, that is good news.  40
Yes, it is, but the trouble is, we can’t seem to find the share certificate.
You wouldn’t happen to have any record of our father’s shares, would you?
I would think so. (Tapping his intercom: ) Would you bring in the shareholder’s ledger, Miss Farthing?
Right away, Mr. Wilkins.
What about your uncle, Mr. Dawes, Jr.? He would know if our father received shares, wouldn’t he? Wilkins sighs, gesturing to a portrait of his uncle.

I'm afraid dear old Uncle Dawes is getting on in years. (He taps his temple.) “Non compos mentis"” - which, sadly, is why I had to take over for him. Ah - thank you, Miss Farthing. Miss Farthing has entered. She hands Wilkins the ledger a leaves. Wilkins flips pages, runs a finger along the colu Aunt Jane WILKINS (cont'd) Let’s see. Babcock, Baker. hmm. There’s no listing of George Banks here. But don’t despair. (Pointing out the window to Big Ben:) You still have until that big fellow out there chimes his last on Friday night to find that certificate. I'll keep searching here as well. and Michael rise.
Thank you so much, Mr. Wilkins. They shake hands. As Michael and Aunt Jane head to the do  4l
Yes, thank you. It was such a pleasure to meet you. Michael and Aunt Jane leave. Wilkins absently takes out h pocket watch, swinging it. He hits his intercom button.
Bring me all of George Banks’ old files, would you?

Of course, Mr. Wilkins. Wilkins walks round to his chair, swinging his pocket-wat and reopens the ledger. He turns to a page with the name GEORGE BANKS written in bold letters. He tears the page o and tosses it into the flames.
The children are already in bedclothes and robes when Mar Poppins enters, carrying a neatly-folded pile of children clothing. She sees Georgie jumping on the bed.
Georgie! This is a nursery, let me remind you, not a music hall.
Can we have another bath?
Oh, pish posh. (Turning: ) John, you'd best go downstairs and - CRASH! From downstairs comes the sound of breaking glass. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) - help Ellen put away the dishes.
Yes, Mary Poppins. He goes. Mary Poppins heads for the wardrobe. Annabel intercepts her, reaching for the clothes.
Here - I can put those away myself.

Very well. Mary Poppins glances to the broken kite which leans again Georgie’s bed. Sternly:  42 MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Georgie Banks - if you’re hoping I‘1l let you take this sadly- neglected kite to the park tomorrow, you had better start patching it up this instant.
(Smiling: ) Yes, Mary Poppins.
Ellen is on a chair, doing her best to put dishes on a hi shelf in the china cabinet. John enters just as Ellen is about to drop them.
Here - let me help you with those.

Oh - there’s a good lad. Such a help you are. (She kicks the broken plates away:) I only wish I could do somethin’ to ‘elp your father save this old house. (A beat. She considers.) I could sell my broach and necklace, I suppose - matching set, my old mum gave ‘em to me. Ellen picks up a large platter and holds it out to John.
You'd do that for us? Ellen pulls the platter away and holds it to her chest.
What?? Sell my prized possessions?
Oh no, I didn’t mean it like that.

Oh, don’t worry. (She hands him the platter. Confidentially: ) I think they’re fakes, anyway. (hands over serving bowl) There’s plenty in this house worth more than them old trinkets. John stares at the china soup tureen he’s holding. He qui passes it back to Ellen and rushes out of the room.  43
If you'll excuse me, Ellen -
What’s got into ‘im?

Georgie sits on his bed, Gillie at his side. He uses scis to cut up his father’s drawing of the family and patches kite with the pieces. Annabel is putting toys back in the chest when John comes rushing back in.
(With quiet urgency: ) Annabel - I know how to save the house!
What do you mean? Mary Poppins enters from her room, crossing to shut the drapes.

If you two are going to keep up all this whispering, I would like you to practice doing so as loudly as possible. It will still be bad manners, but at least then we’ll all be in on the secret. Mary Poppins notices Jack polishing one of the brass lamp the front portico of the house. She opens the window. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Hello, Jack! Jack smiles. He swings himself up onto the portico, climb along the ledge to the nursery window and onto the balcon
Mary Poppins! How are you this fine evening?
Settling in quite nicely, thank you.
(Climbing up:) Y’know, when I was a lad, I used to wave up to the boy and girl who lived here.
You mean Michael and Jane.  44

Miss Jane Banks, that’s right. I see Mr. Banks about now and again -— it’s been ages since I’ve seen her. Now that Mary Poppins’ back is turned, John taps Annabel the shoulder and hurries over to the mantelpiece. They ta in whispers.

She lives in a flat on the other side of town now. I’m sure you’ll bump into her one of these days. Across the room: John takes the china bowl off the mantelpiece. It has an illustration of an autumn scene in park, with leaves falling from the trees. A carriage driv along a winding path. A CLYDESDALE HORSE in mid-gallop is hitched to the carriage. We see the COACHMAN from the bac he wears a top hat and high collar, and holds a whip in h hand.
(Whispering: ) What are you doing? We’re not supposed to touch that.

(Looking closely at the bowl: ) This is authentic Royal Doulton china, Annabel. Mother always said it was priceless, and I bet it’ll be enough to pay off father’s debt. Annabel grabs the bowl off John. He grabs it back from he
That’s a terrible idea, John. Mother loved that bowl.
But she’d sell it herself to save the house. Georgie sees John holding the bowl and hurries over.
That was mother’s - put that back! (Grabbing for the bowl:) Put it back!
Here - give it to me. Jack now sits on the windowsill, chatting with Mary Poppi He lowers his voice, leaning in:  45

It’s a good thing you come along when you did, Mary Poppins. As they tussle, the bowl slips and hits the floor, cracki it and breaking a wedge-shaped piece from the rim. JACK (cont'd) (Wincing: ) That didn’t sound good, now did it? John picks up the bowl. Mary Poppins doesn’t turn.
What are the three of you up to? The children look at one another in a panic. John looks a the bowl, and sees a piece missing.
(An urgent whisper: ) Give me the missing piece!
I haven't got it!
Well look for it then! John places the bowl back on the mantelpiece.
Which of you broke the bowl? The three turn back around. Mary Poppins stands before th Jack behind her. She holds the missing piece in her hand.
Georgie did.
I did not! It was Annabel.
If John hadn't taken it off the mantel! The children all starting arguing at the same time. A voice comes from the bowl behind them.
(Working-class accent: ) Actually, it was all three of them. The children turn, bewildered, glancing over to the door the window, wondering where the voices came from.  46
Who said that? Mary Poppins walks up and peers at the bowl.

Oh, dear. They all peer at the bowl. THE ILLUSTRATION HAS CHANGED - crack has caused one of the carriage wheels to fall off, the carriage has tipped onto its axle. The Horse now star directly out of the bowl at the children, while the Coach peers down at the broken wheel.
Look - the picture’s changed. We see Mary Poppins and the group peering into the bowl f the horses’ “fish-eye lens” point of view.
It looks as though they’ve broken your carriage wheel.
(Irish accent: ) That they have. It’s useless now.
Useless as a chocolate teapot.
The bowl is speaking!
And who do we think is going to fix that?
Ay, there’s the riddle. Them what broke it fixes it. That’s what I say. What do you think, Mary Poppins?
(Irritated: ) I suppose we have no choice.
(Wide-eyed: ) But how are we going to do that?
I know a bit about fixing carriages.
We can’t fix their carriage wheel. It isn’t possible!  47

Everything is possible - even the impossible. Mary Poppins takes the bowl, sets it on a small table in center of the nursery and presses the missing piece back place. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Now, gather ‘round everyone - spit, spot! They do so. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Georgie, don’t forget Gillie! Are we ready?! The children watch in astonishment as Mary Poppins SPINS BOWL on the table. Colorful leaves fly out of the bowl in directions, filling the air and swirling around everyone, covering them completely. When the leaves fall away, they find themselves in...

... the ANIMATED WORLD of the Doulton china bowl. Jack an the children are stunned to discover they’re now wearing of-the-century dress. Mary Poppins holds an elegant paras While they are still very much real, everything around th is animated.
Wow!
What just happened?
Where are we? Jack lifts a finger, tapping the air behind him - we hear ‘tink, tink' of his finger against the bowl.
Looks like we’re in China, so to speak. Mary Poppins slides down a porcelain slope to the carriag

Over here, everyone - this wheel won't fix itself. The others manage the slope much less gracefully;  48 MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Tread lightly, please - this is fine porcelain, we don’t want to chip the glaze. Georgie loses his balance completely and tumbles down to others. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Oh Georgie - head up and feet beneath you. (Turning to the carriage: ) Excuse me, driver, would you help us? The Coachman turns. The children see that he’s actually a IRISH SETTER in uniform.
Well, Mary Poppins! Is it yourself?
But he’s - !
But you’re - !
That's right: I’m Irish - also part poodle. (barks ) Woof!
How wonderful to see you, Shamus. So sorry about all this. Would you help Jack lift the carriage while the children put the wheel back on?
With pleasure!
(Amazed: ) She's talking to a dog!
Well, of course she can talk!

Take your places, everyone. Ready? ... And LIFT! Jack and the Coachman lift the carriage. The children put wheel on. Mary Poppins uses her scarf to tie it in place.  49 MARY POPPINS (cont'd) (As she ties the scarf:) Let’s see now, this should do it. There we are - shipshape.
Not a bad job at all.
S'pose it’1l have to do. Mary Poppins finishes tying the scarf around the wheel.
Back to the nursery we go.
Back already?
Can't we stay in the bowl for a while?
I want a carriage ride.
I wouldn’t mind one m’self.
I suppose it wouldn’t do any harm. Shamus, would you mind?
Not in the least. Climb aboard, everyone!
Hooray!
(As they climb aboard: ) Mind the step. Plant yourselves comfy! Where would you all like to go this fine day?
The Royal Doulton Music Hall, please.
Where?
What’s that?  50
We’re on the brink of an adventure, children - don’t spoil it with too many questions.
Let’s go, Clyde! The Coachman cracks his whip in the air and the horse tro along the cobblestones, hooves clanking on the china. “THE ROYAL DOULTON MUSIC HALL"

head_text.subj: IN THE NURSERY, YOU WERE NEVER

text: Hold on! The carriage climbs up the side of the bowl and turns ups down as it follows the path up the edge of the bowl and crosses over the lip.

head_text.subj: WHERE EACH DAY CROWDS MAKE THEIR WAY

text: UPON THE SUN’S DESCENT
The carriage turns right side up again.
THERE’S A CUDDLY AND CURIOUS
Two hummingbirds lands on Mary Poppins’ finger. She shows them to Jack.

head_text.subj: KNOW THE TUNES AND THE WORDS

text: The hummingbirds flies away, leading us to an elegant fam walking along the path beside them; Jack and the children astounded to see beaks and snouts sticking out from under their parasols and top hats.

Nearly there, Mary Poppins! Georgie climbs to the front of the carriage and sits next Shamus. Jack sits across from Mary Poppins. They pass a giraffe riding a Penny Farthing. Georgie is amazed and shows Gillie the giraffe.
A gang of monkeys swing over the carriage.
THERE’S A LOTTA BIRDS QUEUING UP (A monkey lands on Jack's head: )
Georgie swaps hats with Shamus.

head_text.subj: WAITING FOR THEIR BIG DRUM ROLL

text: Elaborate gates open ahead of them.
They pass through the gates with the words “ROYAL DOULTON MUSIC HALL” scrolled into their ironwork.
The carriage comes to a stop in a large open space.
Here we are!
But... where’s the music hall?  52
Oh, yes - that. Silly me. Mary Poppins opens her parasol and spins it in the air. P BACK TO REVEAL that the parasol has transformed into an enormous...
It is now NIGHTTIME. Mary Poppins, Jack and the children themselves in line at the grand music hall tent, which is festooned with lights. The children are astounded.
Wow!
How on Earth did she do that?
(Shrugs: ) One thing you should know about Mary Poppins - she never explains anything.

Hurry, hurry - only a few seats left! A WOLF with a thin waxed mustache acts as barker, swingin his pocket watch in a manner that makes him look suspicio like Wilkins. A BADGER and a WEASEL selling tickets behin him look remarkably like Gooding and Frye. WOLF (cont'd) Get tickets while you can for the one-night only, one and only - ! (Seeing her:) Mary Poppins! What an honor it is to have you join us this evening.
Thank you.
And who's this I see? Why, it’s John, Annabel and Georgie Banks!
You know us?
Of course - everyone knows the Banks children.  53
We've all been watching you in the nursery for years.
It’s so good to finally meet you.
Hurry along now - get yourselves some peanuts and candy floss and go right on in.
May we, Mary Poppins?
Yes - just keep away from the edge of the bowl. They hurry off.
Inside, DANCING FLAMINGO SHOWGIRLS finish up the pre-show act.

Enthusiastic animal patrons fill the tiered seating that surrounds the stage. Mary Poppins, Jack and the children hurry to front-row seats. John sits down and immediately jumps up again. He turns t see a hedgehog family on the seat beneath him. Mr. Hedgeh doffs his cap. John smiles back and sits one seat in. Applause. Lights out. Drum roll. Rimshot - a spotlight hi center stage. The children are surprised to see Jack, who just next to them, now standing in the spotlight.

Bucks and mares, cubs and does - welcome to our show of shows! Georgie places Gillie in Jack’s now-empty seat. JACK (cont'd) It is my great honor to introduce this evening’s renowned guest... the one, the only MARY POPPINS!  54 The crowd goes wild. Jack bounds to the front of the stag offer her his hand. Mary Poppins joins him onstage.
Sing for us, Mary Poppins!
C’mon - have a go!
(Dismissively: ) Oh, I haven’t sung in years. Four “familiar” PENGUINS peak their heads out from the ce split of the stage curtains.
Please, Mary Poppins? Please...
No, I couldn't possibly. (To the orangutan

D Flat Major. As she steps into the spotlight, the curtains part just enough to reveal a large, open book that acts as a dressi screen, with a bowler hat and hooked cane hanging on it. penguins push the set forward as Mary Poppins steps behin the screen and transforms into character. “BR COVER IS NOT THE BOOK” MARY POPPINS (cont'd)

head_text.subj: AND HE LIVED ON CHARING CROSS
HE WOULD READ ME LOTS OF STORIES
WHEN HE WASN'T ON THE SAUCE
NOW I'D LIKE TO SHARE THE WISDOM

text: The dressing screen flies out, revealing Mary Poppins in costume. The stage curtains open fully, revealing a set composed of piles of enormous books.

head_text.subj: A COVER IS NOT THE BOOK
SO OPEN IT UP AND TAKE A LOOK
CAUSE UNDER THE COVERS ONE DISCOVERS
THAT THE KING MAY BE A CROOK
AND IF YOU READ BETWEEN THE LINES
YOU'LL FIND YOUR FIRST IMPRESSION WAS MISTOOK
FOR A COVER IS NICE BUT A COVER IS NOT THE BOOK

text: Mary Poppins, could you give us an example?

text: The crowd cheers. In the audience, Georgie notices that Gillie is gone. He looks around; the Wolf is CASTING A LA SHADOW onto the canvas wall of the tent as he swings his pocket watch outside. The shadows of the Badger and the Weasel come into view as they cross back and forth carryi things. Georgie recognizes one of the items as Gillie.
Gillie! As Mary and Jack take their bows, Annabel suddenly realiz that Georgie is gone.
Where's Georgie?
I don’t know. They look over just as he leaves through a tent flap. The panic and rush after him.

Georgie comes out of the tent. The Wolf, Badger and Wease stand near a period moving van - a motorized cab with an fashioned steam engine that pulls a slatted wagon.  59 They are loading the wagon with all the real belongings f the children’s nursery (not animated).
What are you doing?
Well, well - if it isn’t the boy who cracked the bowl. We've waited a long time for you Banks children to come and visit us - so we could pay a visit to your nursery.
But those are our things!
Not anymore, they aren't.

Give Gillie back! Georgie rushes at the wagon, grabbing Gillie out of the b The Badger tries to grab it back, but Georgie won't let g GEORGIE (cont'd) He’s mine! My mother made him for me! John and Annabel run out from the tent, shouting.
Hey! Leave our brother alone! The Wolf cranks the engine and climbs into the cab.

Time to go, boys! The Badger and the Weasel throw boy and giraffe together the wagon. They slam the slatted door and jump into the c The moving van roars off through the back gates, engulfin Annabel and John in exhaust smoke...
Annabel! Help! John!
Georgie! John and Annabel chase after Georgie...
+. down far darker, more ominous paths than the lovely cobblestone road that led up to the gates.  60
We're coming Georgie!
(Shouts: ) Let me go! I want to go home!

(Calling back: ) What home? You’ve lost your home! The twins give chase, but the moving van is getting away they slow down, exhausted, when suddenly the carriage dri by the Coachman appears out of the shadows behind them. John and Annabel gasp. A hand reaches down and pulls them into the carriage. Sea turns around to them.
Shamus!
Clyde!
That's right - it’s us!
Let’s go get your brother back! The chase is on. The two vehicles screech and slide on th china’s glazed surface.
We're gaining on them!
Give it more speed! The Badger shovels more coal into the steam engine. As th van banks up the side of the bowl, Georgie is thrown to t side of the tipping wagon. The carriage is closing in.

Giddy up, big fella! The carriage tips and drives up the side of the bowl. The Wolf swerves left and right cutting them off. The carriag closes the gap. COACHMAN (cont'd) (To horse: ) Almost there. John reaches out to Georgie.  61
Georgie! The carriage manages to pull alongside the moving van. Th twins ready themselves. JOHN (cont'd)
- and they leap onto the wagon.
Well done children!
Give ‘em what for! The carriage recedes into the distance.
Get rid of them!
But, sir -
You heard me! The Weasel and the Badger climb out and crawl towards the children. John and Annabel look down at Georgie.
Oh Georgie! Are you alright? John looks up.

Annabel, look. Annabel turns and sees the Badger and Weasel closing in. reaches down, grabs a cricket bat from the nursery belong and swings at the Weasel. The bat misses them and goes flying, chipping the bowl. The chip hits the Badger, who slams into the Weasel, knocking both off the wagon. JOHN (cont'd) (To Annabel: ) Stay with Georgie. Annabel lowers herself into the wagon. She hugs Georgie. watch as John crawls forward.
Be careful!  62
What are you doing? John pulls out the pin, detaching the wagon from the cab.

He did it! John makes his way along the bar back towards the wagon a climbs into the carriage. The Wolf grabs the stoking shovel and swings it hard, hit the bowl and creating a deep crack in the bowl which trav towards the children’s wagon. The wagon wheel hits the crack which splinters off. They up the side of the bowl like a runaway roller coaster. Th Wolf loses control of the cab and careens off a bridge in the water. The frightened children see an ominous sign ahead: “Cauti Edge of Bowl!” ANNABEL (cont'd)
The children scream as the wagon flies off the edge. They fall into space, twisting and turning in slow motion...
Georgie is in his bed, back in his nightclothes again. He tosses and turns in his sleep. Mary Poppins sits next to
It’s alright, Georgie, it’s alright. You were been having a nice sort of nightmare, I must say. Mary Poppins turns on his bedside lamp.
You were right, Mary Poppins! A cover is not the book! We thought they were nice, but they were mean!
Whatever are you talking about?
They tried to take Gillie!  63
Gillie is right here, sleeping - as you should be. She moves the giraffe next to Georgie.
But it was real! They stole all our things, and the wolf said we were never going to see our home again.
That’s absurd. Mary Poppins stands goes to shut the window. She sees Jac cycling away outside, he waves up to her as he goes. John Annabel climb out of their beds, awake as well.
But I had a nightmare like that, too.
(Turning on light:) So did I. It seemed awfully real.
I don’t want to lose our home. Georgie moves over and sits on Annabel’s bed, cuddling Gillie.
You see, Georgie? That’s why we wanted mother’s bowl; we were going to sell it to save the house.
(After a beat.) I miss mother. The room falls silent. Something flickers ever so briefly Mary Poppins’ eyes, and then she speaks.
Listen to the three of you. You’re all worrying far too much. After all, you can’t lose what you’ve never lost.
I don’t understand. “THE PLACE WHERE LOST THINGS GO"

text: Mary Poppins walks out of the nursery, closing the pocket doors that lead to her room. Annabel, gets up, crossing t look out the window at the star.  65 After a moment, she turns to go back to bed, but then she notices the bowl on the mantelpiece. She peers at it, her eyes growing wide.

(Quiet wonder: ) John... look! Mary Poppins’ scarf. It wasn’t a dream after all... John crosses to Annabel’s side. She points at the carriag the bowl; Mary Poppins' scarf is tied around the broken wheel. John is amazed.
Shall we tell her?

We'd better not. I expect she already knows. INT. MARY POPPINS’ BEDROOM —- CONTINUOUS Mary Poppins peers into the nursery through the glass in pocket doors, having quietly listened to this last exchan Satisfied, she steps away from the doors. EXT. ADMIRAL BOOM’S ROOFTOP/ HOUSE AT 17 CHERRY TREE LANE

Aunt Jane walks up the lane to the family home, carrying rally flyers; Jack is dousing the street-lamp in front of house. The door opens on the roof of the Admiral’s house. Binnacle pushes the Admiral out and blows his whistle. Big Ben begins to toll 8 a.m. The Admiral is enraged.
Blast the devil - too soon! Why can’t those pea-brained, Big Ben buffoons get it right?! (Noticing Aunt Jane:) Ahoy, fair lady!
(Turning to wave:) Good morning! She turns back around just as Jack slides down the lamp p The two collide, Aunt Jane’s flyers going everywhere. AUNT JANE (cont'd)
Oh, dear - I am so sorry, miss!  66 He scrambles to help her pick them up.
Oh, it’s alright - thank you - Mary Poppins appears at the nursery window above.
Good morning, Jane - I see you’ve bumped into Jack. The children and I are heading into town to get something fixed. Would you like to come with us?
Work calls, I'm afraid. We have a rally today.
That's right. You ought to give Jack one of those flyers. Mary Poppins disappears from the window. As Jack continue rescuing Aunt Jane’s flyers:
You're Miss Banks, aren’t you? I don’t know if you remember me, but I used to wave to you when I’d see you up there in that very window. In the background, Ellen peers through the letter box.
(Smiling: ) Why, yes - Jack. I remember. Call me Jane, please.
‘Course I was much younger then -
True - but your smile hasn’t changed a bit. (She hands him a flyer.) It’s this afternoon, if you can come.
SPRUCE, eh? Good for you, Jane Banks - all us lamplighters know what a fine job you’re doing for the workers.
We do our best.  67
You ever need a ladder raised or a lamp lit, consider it done.

Why thank you, Jack - Thank you. INT. THE BANKS FRONT ENTRY HALL — CONTINUOUS Ellen is still peering out through the letter box at Jack Aunt Jane when Mary Poppins comes down the stairs carryin the Royal Doulton bowl in a cloth bag. She comes up behin Ellen.
Polishing the keyhole?
Look at that: Miss Jane’s chattin’ with that ‘andsome lamplighter - looks as though he’s lit ‘er up as well, don’t it? Not that anythin’1l ever come of it - she says that ship has sailed.
And I say there are always other ships. Michael rushes down the stairs with his briefcase, panick
My alarm clock didn’t ring!

Oh, dear - let me help you. Mary Poppins puts the bowl down on a side table and TAKES MICHAEL'S BRIEFCASE, handing it to Ellen. Michael gets hi coat from the rack and puts it on while Mary Poppins retrieves his hat and umbrella.
I’m going to be late! That’s all I need. Mary Poppins hands him only his hat and umbrella.
You’re not late yet. Off you go! Mary Poppins opens the door as Michael runs out.  68

location: THE HOUSE AT 17 CHERRY TREE LANE

text: Michael hurries out the front door of the house, barely noticing Jack and Aunt Jane as he passes them. An ELEGANT WOMAN approaches from the opposite direction, holding a p of paper with an address on it.
Good morning, Michael.
(Glancing back: ) Hello - I have to run, forgive me.
Watch where you're going! Michael nearly runs into the ELEGANT WOMAN on the sidewal
Sorry, excuse me — He dodges the woman and hurries off down the street.
(shaking her head) Michael!
No it’s fine. I’m looking for number nineteen...
(together) Just two doors down. They share a laugh.
Many thanks. Sincerely. As the Elegant Woman continues on her way, Ellen rushes o holding his briefcase, followed by Mary Poppins, carrying bowl, and the children.
Michael - your briefcase! (Too late. He’s gone.) He’d leave his ‘ead on the breakfast table if it weren’t screwed on.
Here - I'll take the briefcase. The children and I are heading that way on an errand; we can stop by the bank afterwards.  69
I'll give you a lift. My rounds are done. He turns his ladder sideways, setting it astride and fastening it to the rear fender of the bike. He buckles i up.
Wonderful.
All aboard - come on.
On the bicycle?
But there are five of us. We can’t all fit.
The weight on those wheels alone - Mary Poppins, how much do you weigh?
How...

(Quickly interceding. ) Never you mind about that - it’s a question of balance. Jack kicks off the bike guard as Mary Poppins puts the briefcase in the front basket then holds the bicycle stea JACK (cont'd) (He lifts Annabel onto the bike.) Annabel here, and then John here. He balances them on one side of the ladder.
Careful!
(To the twins.) Sit up straight. You're not flour bags.
Georgie, you’re up front... (He sets Georgie on top of the briefcase.) And Mary Poppins, you here...  70
Thank you. Mary Poppins hops up onto the other side as Jack gets on bike. ON THE ROOFTOP —
Primed and ready, Mr. Binnacle?
Ready and charged, sir. DOWN BELOW -—
Ready everyone?
Ready!
(To Mary Poppins: ) Are you sure this is quite safe?
Not in the slightest. Ready!
Steady... ON THE ROOFTOP —
Three, two, one... FIRE!

Go! BOOM! Jack launches forward. The bike teeters, looking ce to crash, then Jack gets it under control and pedals off. EXT. THE STREET IN FRONT OF COUSIN TOPSY’S SHOP - DAY Jack, Mary Poppins and the children ride the precarious bicycle along a city street.

Pull over right ahead. Thank you, Jack. Jack stops at the entrance to a narrow alley. Mary Poppin takes the bowl as Jack helps the children off the bike. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Off we go, jiggity-jog!  71 EXT. THE ALLEYWAY, COUSIN TOPSY’S SHOP They go down a narrow alleyway past a series of eccentric looking shops.
Never noticed this alley before.

Clearly you’ve never had a Royal Doulton bowl that wanted mending. (Gestures: ) Straight ahead. They arrive at Topsy’s repair shop - a little house at th end with a front door so low that everyone except Georgie would have to duck to go inside. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Here we are. Annabel reads the sign that hangs above the little door:
“TOPOTREPOLOVSKY’S - All Repairs Large and Small Fix-it Shop.”
Looks as though it’s just a Small Fix-it Shop today.
That’s just what we want. The bowl only needs a small fix, after all. She raps on the door with the parrot head of her umbrella
So now my head is a door knocker? I suppose my beak might be useful for opening cans —
“Fuss, fuss, fuss” - don’t be so dramatic. Mary Poppins raps on the door again, hears nothing. She pushes the tip of the umbrella through the letter box. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Cousin Topsy?
(A strangely untraceable Eastern European accent: ) Mary Poppins - NO! For the love of all that is holy, do not come in!  72
Don’t be so rude!
Please stay away, - it is Second Wednesday today!
Second Wednesday... Oh dear, I'd forgotten. Still, today or never - that’s my motto. Mary Poppins forces the tip of the cane into the keyhole thwacks the parrot on the top of the head.
Ouch! She twists the umbrella, opening the lock, and goes insid
(To the others: ) There we are. INT. TOPSY’S WORKSHOP - CONTINUOUS They pass through the tiny door into a narrow entry hall, workshop just ahead.
Follow me.

(Annoyed: ) So in you come. You do not listen to Topsy. Mary reaches the doorway to the workshop. Almost instantly, the entire room begins to rotate, FLIPP UPSIDE DOWN. Nearly everything stays stuck in place. TOPSY (dramatic, Bohemian, a restorations artist of the highest order) is at the top of a spiral staircase on the side of the room; she grips the railings as the room spin TOPSY (cont'd) Oh, no - it has begun! The room comes to a stop with the floor where the ceiling should be. Topsy now sits on the ceiling. A chandelier ju up like a fountain in the middle of the room. TOPSY (cont'd) Now, what do you want?  73
You have guests, cousin. You might at least greet them at the door.
And how am I to do that, please, when I am down here up on the ceiling?

(With a sigh:) Very well, we will come to you. Excuse me please, Georgie. (To the children: ) Now this way please. Be very careful on the way - up. Mary Poppins makes her way gracefully down the piles of broken things, the children and Jack following her.
Why be careful? Leave it all for Topsy to fix. Climb on my shelves, step on the toys, kick the little china dolls in their faces -
John, Annabel, Georgie and Jack - this is my cousin -
Second cousin - many times removed.
Tatiana Antanasia Cositori Topotrepolovsky.
But you may call me Topsy.
(To Topsy: ) That’s an unusual accent you’ve got there - where are you from?
Well, it’s an interesting story...
(Cuts her off:) We have no idea. (Taking the bowl: ) We need you to fix this bowl, dear.
(Reeling back: ) No, no, no no - } (more)  74 TOPSY (cont'd) It is, as I have told to you, the second Wednesday of the month, when everything is turning turtle.
Turning turtle? What exactly does that mean?
It means my whole world goes flippity-flop like a turtle on its back and I don’t know my up from my down, my East from my West - (Flirting with Jack:) - my Topsy from my bottom-sy -
Yes, I think we’ve all grasped the concept.

Oh, good. That’s quick for you. Topsy picks up an instrument that has been badly repaired shows it to the children. TOPSY (cont'd) You see, my little ones? Anything I fix on Second Wednesday goes kerflooey.
(Rolling her eyes:) Kerflooey...
(Nods, grim: ) Yes. Kerflooey. Topsy throws the instrument across the room.
Please, cousin, you’ve always said you could fix anything -
(Turning to Annabel: ) Sweet girl - you tell Mary Poppins, who doesn’t listen, that any other day, Tatiana Antanasia Cositori Topotrepolovsky can fix anything... “TURNING TURTLE”

text: Topsy reaches for the bowl. Jack hands it to her.
Come. Give your bowl to me. No more am I afraid with this new point of view.

In money? (She looks at the bowl, considers for a moment: ) Not very much, I’m afraid. But that doesn’t make it any less beautiful.
But our mother said it was priceless.
Yes, I am sure it was - to her. Disappointment is visible in the eyes of all three childr TOPSY (cont'd) Mary Poppins is right - for once. It is all in the way you look at things.

And don’t you worry about mother’s bowl. I will fix and make perfect for you. So you come back maybe next second Wednesday!

- walking around in a fog.

We're sorry we're late, father. It wasn’t Mary Poppins’ fault.

He means ‘road.’

Best I take my leave. Good night, Mary Poppins.

Ellen is waiting in the front entry hall as everyone ente
Into the parlor - go on. The children obey.

(Turning back, testily:) Of course they’re children - my children - and I will deal with them as I see fit. Now leave us to it.

Not you, Mary Poppins. In here.
Very well, sir. She follows Michael into...

But there you all were, running about — (Turning to Mary Poppins: ) (more)  98 MICHAEL (cont'd) And I thought that you, Mary Poppins - I thought you were here to look after these children.
It wasn’t her doing, it was me.
It was us. We thought maybe if we talked to Mr. Frye, he could give you more time to save the house.

Well, you didn’t help! (A deep breath: ) I know this has been a difficult year for our family, and I have done my best to keep the three of you from worrying - but I can’t do this alone. It’s too much. I’m barely holding on as it is. I can’t even seem to remember my briefcase in the morning, and there is no more time, we're about to lose this house - and I can’t lose our home... I just don’t know what to do anymore, I don’t know what to do. Everything has fallen to pieces since your mother... (Suddenly overcome. ) Haven’t we lost enough already?
