The others put their ladders against the wall and climb u behind him, passing ladders overhead. It is a hair-raisingly dangerous process that looks almos certain to end in disaster. Mary Poppins and the children watch from THE ROOFTOP as J climbs up to a ledge. A pigeon suddenly rushes out at him making him drop his ladder. He loses his balance and hang from the ledge.
I can’t watch! Mary Poppins shakes her head in disapproval.
You would think they’d never done this before.  108 BACK ON THE TOWER, Jack climbs into an arch, having nearl reached the clock’s face. He looks up, realizing the over prevents them from reaching it.
(Calls up to him:) What are we going to do?

(Shouting down: ) I've got an idea! C’mon! Jack jumps into the arch. Angus climbs up onto the ledge outside the arch. Jack calls down to the Leeries below. JACK (cont'd) Ladder! Another Leerie climbs up, a second passes up two ladders, jumping up behind him. They interlock the ladders. Jack places it out over the e like a diving board. He walks out onto the end of the ladder, as two Leeries h it steady from inside the arch. Jack turns round at the very edge, a huge drop below him. steadies himself. ON THE ROOFTOP - the children gasp as they watch Jack fly into the air, backlit by the glowing face of Big Ben’s di AT THE TOWER - Jack lands on the ledge beneath the clock’ face. He opens a small hinged window set into the face of clock and squeezes inside.
Jack squints around the tower, finding the gas main. He cranks it closed, shutting off the gaslights that illumin all the faces of the clock.
The children watch as Big Ben goes dark. Jack sticks his head out of the open window. Angus calls to him.
You can turn the time back now! Jack peers up at the enormous face of the clock.
How? I can’t reach the hands.  109 Down below, Mary Poppins sighs, growing exasperated.
Ohhh - ! Honestly!
They’d better hurry. We have less than a minute to go. Up on the tower, the leeries seem to have run out of idea
We’re too late, Jack!
There’s got to be a way!

Suddenly, Mary Poppins appears, floating before the clock face, holding her umbrella. As she descends, she pushes t minute hand backward five and a half minutes. The leeries cheer. INT. WILKINS’ OFFICE - NIGHT Wilkins sits at his desk, flanked by Gooding and Frye, ey his pocket watch.
Three, two, one and... (Pause. ) Why hasn't Big Ben chimed?
Perhaps your watch is running fast.

Don’t be a simpleton - my watch has never run fast. Wilkins rises from his desk, pushing Frye out of the way, turns toward the window. The clock face on Big Ben is dar WILKINS (cont'd) What’s happened? Big Ben’s gone dark.
Mary Poppins calls down to Jack.

Relight the clock, Jack - quickly!  110 Jack rushes back inside to relight the clock. INT. WILKINS’ OFFICE - NIGHT Wilkins paces in frustration. Suddenly, the clock face on Ben relights in the distance.
Look! They've relit Big Ben.
But that time is wrong - the clock must have stopped. Wilkins glances out the window to the street below, notic a van pulling up. He sees Michael getting out. WILKINS (cont'd) That’s Banks!
(Excited: ) He’s made it in time!
Not yet he hasn’t! Go down there and see that he doesn’t get inside until that blasted clock strikes twelve.
But, sir -
Now, Mr. Frye!

head_text.subj: INT/EXT. THE FRONT DOOR OF THE BANK

text: On the street down below, Michael grabs the kite from the van. Michael and Aunt Jane hurry over to the bank. Just as Michael starts to open the door, though... Gooding and Frye rush through the lobby and grab the door handles from the INSIDE.
Lock it, Mr Frye. OUTSIDE, Michael thinks the door is locked. He knocks.
Hello! Let us in please! We need to get in!  111
Somebody let us in, please. Hello - is anyone there? INSIDE, Frye grows increasingly distraught. OUTSIDE, Michael glances at the kite in his hands.

Jane - let’s go fly a kite! Michael and Aunt Jane run back round the side of the bank desperately try to fly the kite up to Wilkins office. MICHAEL (cont'd) (Points at the window: ) There it is! It’s the one with the light.
Is he there?
I think so, the light’s on.
Ok, here - let me hold it.
I‘1l unspool it. You run. Go on -
One, two, three...

Go! INT/EXT. WILKINS’ OFFICE/BANK DOORS - CONTINUOUS/INTERCUT As Wilkins settles into his office chair, the kite flies view outside the window behind him. DOWN BELOW, Michael and Aunt Jane are flying the kite, tr to position it outside the balcony so Wilkins will see it

It won’t work - He’s never going to see it! As BIG BEN BEGINS TO TOLL MIDNIGHT, Mary Poppins appears the sky behind Michael and Aunt Jane, umbrella in hand. S takes a breath and gently blows. The wind rises, the wind fly open and the kite breaks free from its string... «+. floating into WILKINS’ OFFICE. It hits Wilkins in the back of the head, before landing on his desk.  112 DOWN BELOW - Michael and Aunt Jane rush back to pull on t bank doors. INSIDE, Gooding continues to resist - but Frye can’t take anymore. He lets go of the handle and steps back. Gooding goes sprawling as the door swings open and Michael and Au Jane rush inside, thinking the men have unlocked the door
Oh - thank you so much.
Thank you!
Hurry, Mr. Banks! Frye catches Gooding glaring at him.
What! In the OFFICE, Wilkins stares at the kite on his desk, bewildered. He sees the words “Certificate of Shares” pee through a hole in the kite.
What is this? Michael bursts through the open door just as Big Ben chim its final note.
It’s what we’ve been looking for. EXT. CHERRY TREE LANE, THE ADMIRAL’S ROOFTOP - CONTINUOUS

Three, two, one... FIRE! Binnacle fires the cannon - BOOM! The Admiral nods, impre ADMIRAL BOOM (cont'd) Mr. Binnacle - Big Ben has finally got it right. INT. WILKINS’ OFFICE - A FEW MINUTES LATER Michael gently peels a piece of the share certificate off kite. Wilkins, Aunt Jane, Mary Poppins, Jack, the childre and the lawyers watch as he places it with the rest of th share certificate, which lies on the desk - in fragments, nearly complete.
And this one goes here...  113
Does it matter if it’s all cut up in bits? Is it still worth anything?
It’s valid so long as all the pieces are there.
(Through gritted teeth: ) Is that so? Michael examines the kite, searching for the final piece. It’s not there.
Georgie, there was one more piece - a corner piece with a lot of signatures. Do you remember it?
I must have thrown it out. I’m sorry, father.
Oh, it’s alright, Georgie -
No, it isn’t. I’m afraid you have a problem, Banks. Without those signatures, you have no bank shares, no house - you have nothing. Michael turns, looking at Wilkins with new eyes.
What?
But he knows you have bank shares!
He’s been planning this all along!
Take your children out of here, Banks. I’ve heard enough of their lies.

(Eyes blazing with anger: ) Don’t you dare insult my children - don’t you DARE! They’re not lying and you know it. I only wish I had believed them sooner. (Turning to his children: ) (more)  114 MICHAEL (cont'd) You all had him pegged right from the start. (To Wilkins: ) Take the house - go ahead. (Putting his arms around the children: ) I have everything I need right here. A double door that leads into an adjacent boardroom swing open. MR. DAWES, JR. enters (80s - full of vigor). MR. DAWES, JR. He has you there, Willie.
Uncle Dawes?? What on earth are you doing here? MR. DAWES, JR. A little bird told me that you’ve been trying to cheat the Banks family out of their shares in Fidelity Fiduciary.

That he has, we heard him. Dawes glances over to Mary Poppins’ parrot umbrella. The umbrella gives him a sly wink. MR. DAWES, JR. I also hear you've been telling the whole of London I’ve gone loony. The only loony thing I did is trust you to look after this bank.

You can’t be serious! I’ve nearly doubled the profits of this bank. MR. DAWES, JR. Yes, by wringing it out of our customer's pockets. Their trust in us built this bank - and now you've squandered every last bit of their good will. So I’m back, and you're out. (To Gooding and Frye:) See my nephew to the door, would you, gentlemen?
Yes, sir, Mr. Dawes. The lawyers take Wilkins by an arm, leading him to the do  115

Get your hands off me - (Shrugs them off:) You’re not fit to run this bank! They are gone. MR. DAWES, JR. We'll see about that. I may be circling the drain, but I still have a few steps left in me. Mr. Dawes, Jr. kicks up his heels in a little SONG AND DA “TRIP A LITTLE LIGHT FANTASTIC” - reprise MR. DAWES, JR. (cont'd) SO... WHEN... THEY...

head_text.subj: AND YOUR CHANCE TO DANCE IS DONE

text: THAT’S THE TIME TO STAND
AND TELL ‘EM THAT YOU'VE JUST
SO WHEN LIFE’S A REAL PEA-SOUPER

head_text.subj: YOU MUST CHOOSE TO BE A TROUPER
FOR YOUR LIGHT COMES WITH A

text: Mr. Dawes, Jr. dances onto the top of his desk.
+. Dawes hops off the desk and sits in his old chair as t children skip round him.
(Gesturing to his legs) Children, help me with my legs. The children help lift Mr. Dawes’s leg off the table.
So glad to have you back, Mr. Dawes.  116 MR. DAWES, JR. Thank you, Michael. And by the way - those shares of yours are perfectly fine - save them for your family.

I’m sorry, I don’t understand - MR. DAWES, JR. I'd like to tell you a little story. They gather beside him. As “FEED THE BIRDS” plays under: MR. DAWES, JR. (cont'd) Once upon a time there was a man with a wooden leg named Smith - Oh no, no, no. Not that one. There was little boy named Michael who wanted to give his tuppence to a bird lady - but in the end, and after a little persuasion, he decided to give it to his father instead. Michael’s father - your grandfather - gave that tuppence to this bank and he asked us to guard it well. We did just that, and thanks to several quite clever investments - if I do say so myself... (Turning to Michael: ) That tuppence has grown into quite a sum!

Really? MR. DAWES, JR. (With a smile:) Really, Michael. Enough, in fact, to pay off that loan you took. The house is yours. The Banks children rush to hug their father. Mary Poppins off to the side, allows herself a little satisfied grin.
The NEXT MORNING - Spring has arrived on swift wings. Che trees rustle in the breeze, heavy with new blossoms. Mary Poppins, Ellen and the family walk down the lane to the B home.
What a beautiful day to be going back home again.  117
Look at these lovely cherry blossoms!
Yes, they are. I’1ll have to paint them. What about you, Jane?
What about me?
(Jumping in:) He means what about you and that handsome lamplighter, Jack?
No, no, no - we’re just friends. Really.
(Tongue in cheek: ) Mmm-hmm... go on.

(Looking ahead: ) What’s this? Through the park gates, they see that colorful tents have been set up in the center of the green. Crowds stand in l for food carts, games of chance, and a small Ferris wheel
The Spring Fair - it’s today! Can we go?
Please?
I don’t see why not.
Hooray! The children surround their father, urging him along with them as they rush into the park.
Come on, Father - let’s go!
Will you go on the Ferris wheel with us?
Yes, yes - and you too, Jane!  118
(Taking Ellen’s arm:) Only if Ellen comes with me.
I wouldn’t be caught dead on that thing... The family hurries ahead, as their voices trail off. Mary Poppins slows, a knowing look in her eyes as she watches go on ahead without her.

location: THE SPRING FAIR AT THE PARK

text: The family arrives at the fair. There are familiar faces the crowd: Miss Lark and Willoughby, the Milkman - even t Park Keeper, having a miserable time watching everyone trample over his grass. A street organ begins to play. CLOSE on a bundle of balloons. WE CIRCLE ROUND to reveal BALLOON LADY - a kind-hearted street vendor who is perhap little bit magical. “NOWHERE TO GO BUT UP”
LIFE’S A BALLOON
THEN YOU’RE IN FOR A RIDE...

text: THERE’S NOWHERE TO GO BUT UP Georgie sees a bundle of balloons across the fairgrounds.
May we have balloons?
Of course we can. Let’s go. The family run across the grass.
THERE’S NOWHERE TO GO BUT UP They approach the Balloon Lady.  119
(Holds out coins:) Hello - we would like some of your very finest balloons, please.
That you shall have. But choose carefully, my dearie ducks. Many have chosen the wrong balloon - be sure to choose the one that’s right for you.
Which one would you like, Georgie?
Umm...
Why don’t you go first, sir? Michael hesitates.
Me? Those days are long behind me. I don’t think I’ve held a balloon since I was a child.
Then you've forgotten what it’s like.
(Amused: ) To hold a balloon?
To be a child.
As Michael reaches inside the bundle, choosing a balloon:

THEN YOUR HEART WILL TAKE WING

Michael!  120

text: AND THERE’S NOWHERE TO GO BUT UP He looks back to Aunt Jane, overcome with joy: Jane - I remember! It’s all true! Every impossible thing we imagined with Mary Poppins - it all happened! Michael soars into the sky.

THAT I THINK I JUST MIGHT
AND THEN GO FLY A KITE

WE’RE ZIGGING AND ZAGGING

AND THAT’S AN IMPORTANT THING He sees Aunt Jane turn to look into the bundle for her ow ‘right’ balloon.

text: He picks out a balloon, offering it to her. JACK (cont'd) This one looks like you. Aunt Jane gazes into the balloon, smiles.  121
How do you know? And with that, Aunt Jane floats up into the air. Admiral and Binnacle come through the crowd, having watched this whole exchange.
Don’t you lose her, son! Jack takes a balloon. As he floats off, calling back:
I won't, sir! Jack rises up in the air to float beside Aunt Jane.
IT’S A MARVELOUS VIEW!

BUT NOW I AM PART OF

Would you like to try one yourself, sir?
Why not - I’ll give it a go.

Alright, love. Choose carefully. He chooses a balloon, but instead of lifting him in the a it slowly sinks to the ground. He looks to the Balloon La BALLOON LADY (cont'd) Well... ...THERE’S NOWHERE TO GO BUT UP UP ABOVE, Ellen rises quickly into the air, passing the family.

text: 123 EXT. THE PARK —- CONTINUOUS Mary Poppins stands in the park, gazing at the people floating above, umbrella in hand and carpet bag at her si The Balloon Lady comes over.
Of course, the grown-ups will all forget by tomorrow.
They always do.
Only one balloon left, Mary Poppins. I think it must be yours.

I suppose it must. The Balloon Lady passes Mary Poppins the balloon - a red then leaves. Mary Poppins looks inside the balloon, and s an image of herself, looking very much as she always look She nods, satisfied. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Practically Perfect in every way. As Mary Poppins gazes at the balloon, her own image fades instead, she sees Michael, Aunt Jane, Ellen and the child floating down...
-..to land on the street in front of their house.
Welcome home, everyone.
It’s nice to be back, isn’t it?

It is - so nice. I never thought I'd feel this much joy and wonder ever again. I thought that door was closed to me forever. At that moment, A STRONG GUST OF WIND BLOWS, swirling che blossoms around them and THROWING THE FRONT DOOR WIDE OPE  124
The same wind sweeps across the park, cherry blossoms cascading down around Mary Poppins as well. Her balloon s from her fingers and swirls up into the sky.
The children run excitedly into the house - which has bee fully restored to its former state. Ellen goes up the ste following the children inside.

It’s time. She opens her umbrella, raises it up into the breeze and floats into the air... EXT. THE BANKS HOME —- CONTINUOUS As the last of the cherry blossoms fall, Aunt Jane looks at Michael and realizes the truth.
She's gone, hasn’t she, Michael?
(He nods. Quietly:) Thank you, Mary Poppins. Goodbye.
